SEARCH
Module org.klojang.jdbc
Package org.klojang.jdbc

Interface BeanExtractor<T>

Type Parameters:
T - the type of the JavaBeans or records produced by the BeanExtractor
All Superinterfaces:
Iterable<T>
public sealed interface BeanExtractor<T> extends Iterable<T>

Converts the rows in a JDBC ResultSet into JavaBeans or records. Instances are obtained via BeanExtractorFactory.getBeanifier(). A BeanExtractor is agnostic about, and has no opinion on how the ResultSet was obtained. It may have been produced using regular JDBC calls. It does not aim to be an ORM-like class. It just converts result sets into (flat) JavaBeans, to be carried across the boundary of the data access module (and into the view layer, for example). The JavaBeans may have nested structures, but only top-level properties will be populated.

BeanExtractor is an extension of the Iterable interface, enabling you to extract the JavaBeans in a forEach loop: 


 ResultSet rs = ...;
 BeanExtractorFactory factory = new BeanExtractorFactory(Employee.class);
 for(Employee emp : factory.getBeanifier(rs)) {
   // do stuff ...
 }

JavaBeans vs. Records

When converting a row into a JavaBean, a BeanExtractor will always use the setters on the JavaBean to populate it. There is no way to populate the bean via its constructors. When converting to a record, a BeanExtractor will obviously always use one of its constructors to populate it. Make sure the record has a constructor for those record components that are supposed to map to columns in the SELECT clause. The encounter order of the record components within the constructor must match the encounter order of the columns in the SELECT clause. However, it is not necessary that each record component can be mapped to a column in the SELECT clause, and it is not necessary that each column in the SELECT clause can be mapped back to a record component.
Author:
Ayco Holleman

  • Method Details

    • extract

      Optional<T> extract()
      Converts the current row within the ResultSet into a JavaBean. If the ResultSet is empty, or if there are no more rows in the ResultSet, an empty Optional is returned. You can keep calling extract() to successively extract all rows in the result set until you receive an empty Optional, or until isEmpty() returns true.
      Returns:
      an Optional containing the JavaBean or an empty Optional if the ResultSet contained no (more) rows

    • extract

      List<T> extract(int limit)
      Converts at most limit rows from the ResultSet into JavaBeans, possibly less, if there are not that many rows left in the ResultSet. If the ResultSet is empty, or if there are no more rows in the ResultSet, an empty List is returned.
      Parameters:
      limit - the maximum number of rows to extract and convert
      Returns:
      a List of JavaBeans or an empty List if the ResultSet contained no (more) rows

    • extractAll

      List<T> extractAll()
      Converts all remaining rows in the ResultSet into JavaBeans.
      Returns:
      a List of JavaBeans or an empty List if the ResultSet contained no (more) rows

    • extractAll

      List<T> extractAll(int sizeEstimate)
      Converts all remaining rows in the ResultSet into JavaBeans.
      Parameters:
      sizeEstimate - an estimate of the size of the resulting List.
      Returns:
      a List of JavaBeans or an empty List if the ResultSet contained no (more) rows

    • isEmpty

      boolean isEmpty()
      Returns true if the end of the ResultSet has been reached; false otherwise.
      Returns:
      whether the end of the ResultSet has been reached
